Original item:
NA
(adapted from https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3313831.3376435 )
Current item for digital self-control: In the past week, on average, approximately how much time PER DAY have you spent actively using your INSERT DEVICE?
Notes: UL: this question should be asked for each digital device they check

Original item: Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think. For each statement, please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the statement. If you Agree Strongly circle 1, if you Agree Somewhat circle 2, if you Disagree somewhat circle 3, and if you Disagree Strongly circle 4. Be sure to indicate your agreement or disagreement for every statement below.
Current item for digital self-control:
version w/ dynamic text based on previous answers:

Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think in relation to their digital devices.

Please indicate how much you agree or disagree with each statement in relation to your (INSERT DEVICES THE PARTICIPANT CHECKED).
Alternate version:
version w/ static text:

Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think in relation to their digital devices.

Please indicate how much you agree or disagree with each statement in relation to the digital devices you use.
Notes:
UL: Plan A is to use the current item when it's possible to adjust the question dynamically (I can do this using formr) 
MI: I like the alternate actually, as I think the Qs shoudl pertain to all devices not just the one they most use
KL: I prefer the current item when you can generate dynamically based on the devices they use, but the alternate is simpler to implement and works too. 

KL: One side question: are we intentionally excluding other digital devices, i.e., gaming consoles, smart speakers, VR headsets, internet-connected TVs, etc.? These are clearly digital devices, so we should have some rationale for including/excluding, which might just be that our workshop interventions aren't targeted towards those devices?

Original item: I have trouble controlling my impulses
Current item for digital self-control: I have trouble controlling my impulses when using digital devices

Notes: UL: changed to 'when using' instead of v1's 'go on', because three other items are already focused on impulsive checking (full: #7, #39, #53)

Original item: I generally seek new and exciting experiences and sensations.
Current item for digital self-control: I generally seek new and exciting experiences and sensations online
Notes:
UL: closest I think is the "Problematic and Risky Internet Use Screening Scale (PRIUSS) for adolescents and young adults": https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0747563214000478 
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1876285915002223 

Items on their factor 3, "Risky and Impulsive Internet Use":
Allow time on the internet to negatively affect your school performance
Lose motivation to do other things that need to get done 
Neglect responsibilities
Avoid other activities in order to stay online
Put internet use in front of important, everyday activities
Lose sleep due to nighttime internet use
Use the internet excessively

In general, the things researchers talk about in relation to risky behaviour online are "[exposure] to a variety of sexual and violent material, financial scams, cyber bullying, harassment, and the risk of meeting dangerous people or even sexual predators" https://journals.lww.com/cinjournal/fulltext/2011/06000/Risky_Internet_Behaviors_of_Middle_School.6.aspx 

Kai: Two quick thoughts here re: adapting these SS items for digital self-control:
1) It seems that these items come from another scale (the Zuckerman SSS-V) that itself has subscales: https://scienceofbehaviorchange.org/measures/zuckerman-sensation-seeking-scale-v/ We might want to try to make our adapted items also capture items that fit with those corresponding subscales.
2) Maybe there's already a scale of "sensation-seeking online" or "risky behaviors online" that we can borrow/adapt from?

Original item: Before I get into a new situation I like to find out what to expect from it.
Current item for digital self-control: Before I try new apps or services on my digital devices I like to find out what to expect from them
Alternate version: (R) Once I start using my digital device, it is hard for me to stop
Previous versions: v1 Before I get on my digital devices I like to think about what to expect from it
Notes:
UL: the underlying tension is to what extent we stick closely to the items from the original scale vs ensure all the concerns ppl typically raise about digital self-control are covered

UL: if 'stickiness' = unintended long use, then I don't think it always represents lack of premeditation. Many people say they pick up a DD to do one thing but then forget their initial goal and do something else. Inability to stop when you've started something isn't really the same as premeditation, is it?

MI: as with the item below, we need items that capture the stickiness of DD, which I think represents lack of premeditation

When overjoyed, I start using my digital devices and can't stop from going too far
Notes:
UL: The interesting challenge with this item is that positive urgency does not really come up in digital self-control research --- it's all about negative urgency where ppl struggle to regulate their social media use when in a bad mood. Though maybe some impulse shopping could be driven by positive urgency
